abstract.text: Word count: 2555 45 Word count of abstract: 239 46 Number of tables: 1; Number of figures: 5 47 Number of supplementary figures: 5 48 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission. ABSTRACT 49 Background and Aims: Cumulating observations have indicated that patients with 50 coronavirus disease (COVID-19) undergo different patterns of liver impairment. We 51 performed a meta-analysis of published liver manifestations and described the liver 52 damage in COVID-19.

53 Methods: We searched PubMed, Google Scholar, Embase, Cochrane Library, 54 medRxiv, bioRxiv, and three Chinese electronic databases through April 18, 2020, in 55 accordance with the Preferred Reporting Items for Meta-Analyses. We analyzed 56 pooled data on liver chemistries stratified by COVID-19 severity using a fixed or 57 random-effects model. 58 Results: In the meta-analysis of 37 studies, which included a total of 6,235 patients, 59 the pooled mean alanine aminotransferase (ALT) was 36.4 IU/L in the severe 60 COVID-19 cases and 27.8 IU/L in the non-severe cases (95% confidence interval [CI]: 61 −9.4 to −5.1, p < 0.0001). The pooled mean aspartate aminotransferase (AST) was 62 46.8 IU/L in the severe cases and 30.4 IU/L in the non-severe cases (95% CI: −15.1 to 63 −10.4, p < 0.0001). Furthermore, regardless of disease severity, the AST level is often 64 higher than the ALT level. Compared with the non-severe cases, the severe cases 65 tended to have higher γ-glutamyltransferase levels but lower albumin levels. 66 Conclusions: In this meta-analysis, we comprehensively described three patterns of 67 liver impairment related to COVID-19, namely hepatocellular injury, cholestasis, and 68 hepatocellular disfunction, according to COVID-19 severity. Patients with abnormal 69 liver test results are at higher risk of progression to severe disease. Close monitoring 70 of liver chemistries provides an early warning against disease progression.

body_text.text: 4 Lay Summary 74 Data on abnormal liver chemistries related to coronavirus disease (COVID-19) are 75 cumulating but are potentially confusing. We performed a meta-analysis of 37 studies 76 that included a total of 6,235 patients with COVID-19. We noted that patients with 77 abnormal liver test results are at higher risk of progression to severe disease and close 78 monitoring of liver chemistries provides early warning against disease progression.

The patients with 236 COVID-19 often had higher AST levels than ALT levels, especially in severe cases. 237 We also observed a tendency of the severe cases to arise in the elderly.

FIGREF0.text: 84 controlled in mainland China, the spread and upward trend of COVID-19 have 85 accelerated dramatically worldwide. In response to the emerging threat posed by 86 COVID-19, caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-87 2), the WHO has declared a Public Health Emergency of International Concern on 88 January 30, 2020, which was further labeled as a pandemic on March 11, 2020. 89 Similarly, the other two previously identified coronaviruses, namely SARS-CoV and 90 Middle East Respiratory Syndrome-CoV, SARS-CoV-2 causes severe viral 91 pneumonia in humans. As no specific acquired immunity exists in the general 92 population, SARS-CoV-2 has high infectivity, which has resulted in an ongoing 93 global health crisis. 94 Apart from the respiratory system, the urinary system, gastrointestinal tract, and even 95 the central nervous system are the probable target organs of SARS-CoV-2, which 96 utilizes the angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) receptors of the respiratory and 97 gastrointestinal tracts as the entry point for epithelial cells [2]. Among patients' 98 common complaints related to COVID-19 are gastrointestinal symptoms, including 99 nausea/vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain [3-6]. Abundant ACE2 protein 100 expression in the glandular cells of gastric, duodenal, and rectal epithelia supports the 101 entry of SARS-CoV-2 into the host epithelial cells [7]. Single-cell RNA sequencing 102 has revealed a specific ACE2 expression in cholangiocytes [8]. Thus, performing liver 103 chemistry tests for a number of patients with COVID-19 seems reasonable. In fact, 104 several studies have found liver injury in patients with COVID-19 [9-13].

FIGREF2.text: Considering the diverse clinical manifestations and increasing number of reported 112 COVID-19 cases, a systematic summary of the liver manifestations of COVID-19 is 113 urgently needed. 114 Liver chemistries generally consist of hepatocellular injury-related indexes, including 115 alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST); cholestatic 116 injury-related indexes, comprised of alkaline phosphatase (AKP) and -117 glutamyltransferase (GGT); and hepatocellular function-related indexes such as 118 albumin (ALB) level and prothrombin time (PT) [14] . In general, total bilirubin (TBIL), 119 direct bilirubin (DBIL), and globulin (GLB) levels, and international standardized 120 ratio (INR) are also assessed in clinical practice. However, observations to 121 comprehensively analyze liver chemistries in patients with COVID-19 patients are 122 rather few. Hence, the aim of this study was to provide a comprehensive view of liver 123 test parameters in patients with severe and non-severe COVID-19. With better 124 knowledge, more targeted therapies and holistic care approaches could be developed.

FIGREF5.text: identified, 37 studies were included in the meta-analysis. The characteristics 176 of the enrolled studies are listed in Table 1 [9, 12, 13, 18-51]. Information, including 177 the study location, sample size, patient age and sex, disease severity, INR, PT, and 178 TBIL, DBIL, ALT, AST, GGT, AKP, ALB, and GLB levels, was recorded. The mean 179 ages of patients with non-severe and severe COVID-19 were 51.1 and 64.0 years, 180 respectively (Supplementary Figure 1). In the enrolled studies, male patients 181 accounted for 54.6%. Among the studies that reported disease severity, severe disease 182 accounted for 30.3% (range, 8.0-54.8%) of the cases.

FIGREF6.text: Hepatocellular injury-related abnormalities in liver chemistries184    Of the enrolled studies, 37 reported assays of ALT or AST in a total of 6,235 patients185 with COVID-19. All but one of these studies were from China. Of the 36 enrolled 186 studies from China, 16 (44.4%) were from Hubei Province, where Wuhan is located. 187 The pooled mean ALT level was 36.4 IU/L in the patients with severe COVID-19 and 188 27.8 IU/L in the patients with non-severe COVID-19 (95% CI: −9.4 to −5.1, p < 189 0.0001; Figure 2A), with significant heterogeneity among the studies (I 2 = 69%, p < 190 0.01). Similarly, the pooled mean AST level was 46.8 IU/L in the severe cases and 191 30.4 IU/L in the non-severe cases (95% CI: −15.1 to −10.4, p < 0.0001;

FIGREF8.text: Cholestasis-related abnormalities in liver chemistries201    Compared with the studies that reported ALT and AST levels, rather fewer studies202 focused on cholestasis-related indexes such as AKP, GGT, and DBIL levels. Of the 203 enrolled studies for the meta-analysis, 8 reported AKP assays and 5 studies reported 204 GGT measurements. The pooled mean AKP level was 66.2 IU/L in the patients with 205 severe COVID-19 and 61.0 IU/L in those with non-severe COVID-19 (95% CI: −11.2 206 to 0.1, p > 0.05; Figure 4A). The pooled mean GGT level was 43.2 IU/L in the severe 207 group and 30.7 IU/L in the non-severe group (Figure 4B). The pooled mean TBIL 208 level in the severe group was slightly higher than that in the non-severe group.209However, the mean TBIL levels in both groups remained within the normal range 210 (Figure 4C). Even fewer studies reported DBIL values in patients with COVID-19. In 211 fact, no significant difference in mean DBIL level was found between the 2 groups 212 (Figure 4D). For the TBIL levels, low heterogeneity was observed among the studies 213 (I 2 = 14%, p = 0.26). A funnel plot for the TBIL levels is shown in Supplementary

FIGREF9.text: as PT and INR, no significant differences were found between the 224 severity groups. The patients in the severe group tended to have longer PT or higher 225 INR (Figure 5C, 5D). An evaluation of publication bias in relation to ALB

FIGREF10.text: 240 report cholestasis-related indexes such as AKP and GGT levels, and synthetic 241 function-related indexes such as ALB level and INR. Moreover, most studies reported 242 ALT/AST levels on the day of admission but not throughout the disease course. This 243 issue further compromises the role of liver chemistries in disease monitoring and 244 provides an early warning against severe cases. As SARS-CoV-2 can lead to bile duct 245 damage by conquering the ACE2 expressed on cholangiocytes and induce a 246 subsequent cholestatic liver injury [8], cholestasis-related abnormalities could be 247 overlooked. 248 Cumulating studies have linked abnormal liver chemistries to the severity of COVID-249 19 [9, 19, 25]. Patients with abnormal liver test results are at higher risk of 250 progression to severe disease [9]. In fact, coronavirus infection can cause direct 251 damage to liver cells [11]. Moreover, several underlying diseases, comorbidities, and 252 complications that develop in the course of the disease, such as sepsis and multiple-253 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF11.text: failure, and drugs that can cause potential liver damage also increase the risk of 254 liver injury. Lopinavir/ritonavir use during hospitalization has been reported to 255 possible lead to liver damage [9, 52]. The liver chemistry tests in the enrolled studies 256 were all performed on admission, which suggests that the influences of the drugs on 257 the liver tests, if any, should be minor. 258 ALB level and PT are known to reflect hepatocellular function. Albumin, which has a 259 circulating half-life of 3 weeks, is a plasma protein exclusively synthesized by the 260 liver [53]. Hypoalbuminemia results from and reflects the inflammatory state, which 261 leads to inflammatory exudate. Effective nutrition support helps to correct 262 hypoalbuminemia [54]. Our meta-analysis revealed that ALB level was lower in the 263 severe cases than in the non-severe cases, which indicated that the severe cases tended 264 to have more intense inflammation and require more solid nutrition support. PT is a 265 far more sensitive measure of hepatocellular function than ALB level because PT may 266 be prolonged in patients with severe liver disease duration of <24 h [14]. In 267 accordance with the alteration of the ALB level, PT was prolonged in the severe cases, 268 which further indicated impairment of hepatocellular function in the severe cases [53]. 269 According to our meta-analysis, another interesting feature of liver impairment related 270 to COVID-19 is that the AST level often overrides the ALT level, especially in severe 271 cases. By contrast, in patients with chronic hepatitis B or nonalcoholic fatty liver 272 disease, the ALT level is generally higher than the AST level. Although ALT is 273 present primarily in the liver and is a more specific marker of hepatocellular injury, 274 the distribution of AST is far wider than that of ALT, including the cardiac muscle, 275 skeletal muscle, kidney, and brain [14]. An elevated AST level accompanied by a 276 normal ALT level often suggests cardiac or muscle disease. In fact, cardiac injury is 277 frequent in severe cases of COVID-19, especially in deceased patients [25, 55].

FIGREF13.text: more precise evaluation of the abnormalities of liver chemistries. Our 282 subgroup analysis revealed that the abnormal liver chemistries were associated with a 283 more severe disease course, highlighting the importance of a more extensive 284 monitoring of liver chemistries for both diagnostic and prognostic purposes.

FIGREF14.text: Second, this analysis extensively covered all three patterns of liver impairment,286    namely hepatocellular injury, cholestasis, and hepatocellular dysfunction. Most 287 observations focused on ALT, AST, and ALB levels. However, cholestasis-related 288 impairment (e.g., abnormal AKP and GGT levels) tended to be inadvertently ignored.289Moreover, we also compared hepatocellular dysfunction between the severe and non-290 severe cases. The alarmingly high prevalence of hypoalbuminemia in the severe cases 291 prompts further nutrition support in severe cases. In addition, coagulation dysfunction 292 in severe cases requires vigilance. Third, the enrolled studies included multiple 293 observations not only from mainland China but also from other ethnic groups. This 294 facilitates the assessment of abnormal liver chemistries related to COVID-19 in a 295 broader ethnic context. Fourth, eligible studies preprinted in medRxiv and bioRxiv 296 were also covered, which ensured that our analysis has a clear leading position. 297 However, our study has a few limitations. As mentioned earlier, cholestasis-related 298 indexes such as AKP/GGT level may be under-reported in quite a number of studies, 299 which may lead to less precise pooled data. Second, most studies came from mainland 300 China, which precluded a more precise estimate of the abnormalities of liver 301 chemistries in the other ethnic groups. Most of the studies that came from mainland 302

However, this study still enrolled 334 studies that reported individual liver chemistry indexes if the severity of COVID-19 335 was reported in relation with the index.

TABREF1.text: Furthermore, cumulating observations have indicated that different patterns of abnormal liver chemistries exist between patients with severe and non-severe COVID-19. Although liver manifestations of COVID-19 pose an important diagnostic 108 challenge to clinicians when treating patients with symptoms related to COVID-19 on initial presentation, these are potentially useful for recognizing severe cases of COVID-19 in the early stage.

TABREF2.text: The eligibility of the potential studies was determined independently by two authors 139 (XD and WMC), and dissonance was arbitrated by the third author (JSP). The inclusion criteria were as follows: (1) study population: adult COVID-19 patients; (2) study design: case series, case report, prospective cohort study, retrospective cohort142 study, case-control study, and randomized controlled trial; and (3) language: studies 143 published in English or Chinese. The exclusion criteria were as follows: (1) pediatric patients or pregnant women; (2) patients without nucleic acid data or serology 145 evidence of SARS-CoV2 infection; (3) asymptomatic patients with SARS-CoV2 infection; (3) study design: review article, meta-analysis, editorial, or commentary.

TABREF3.text: For the eligible articles, we recorded the following items: first author, study location, sample size, patient age and sex, and liver chemistry-related indexes such as ALT, AST, TBIL, DBIL, GGT, AKP, and ALB levels. The severity of COVID-19 was also normal distribution were expressed as mean ± SD, while those that conformed to a skewed distribution were expressed as median (interquartile range[IQR]). For the 160 studies that provided summary data of median, minimum, and maximum values, we used the method developed by Luo et al [16] to estimate the sample mean and SD for 162 the continuous outcomes. The online tool used is provided at http://www.math.hkbu.edu.hk/~tongt/papers/median2mean.html. The 95% confidence interval (CI) was presented as a Forest plot. The Cochran Q test was used to detect the heterogeneity among studies, with a p value of <0.10 indicating significant heterogeneity. The I 2 statistics was calculated to measure the proportion of total variation among the studies to which the heterogeneity was attributed. I 2 values of <25%, 25-75%, and >75% represent low, moderate, and high heterogeneity, respectively [17]. Publication bias was evaluated using a funnel plot. A subgroup analysis was performed according to disease severity.

TABREF5.text: In this meta-analysis, 37 studies that consisted a total of 6,235 patients with COVID-19 from China and the United States were enrolled. According to the pooled analysis, three patterns of liver impairment, namely hepatocellular injury, cholestasis, and hepatocellular dysfunction, can develop in a proportion of patients with COVID-19 at variable severity. In brief, the patients with severe COVID-19 tended to have higher

TABREF6.text: In this meta-analysis, we comprehensively described three patterns of liver impairment related to COVID-19, namely hepatocellular injury, cholestasis, and hepatocellular dysfunction, according to COVID-19 severity.
